quoteLast: some of the cruisers ahead, under Rear-Admirals Herbert L. Heath, M.V.O., and Sir Robert Arbuthnot, Bt., M.V.O., were seen to be in action, and reports received show that _Defence_, flagship, and _Warrior_, of the First Cruiser Squadron, engaged an enemy light-cruiser at this time. She was subsequently observed to sink.
title: World's War Events, Vol. II
author: Reynolds, Francis J. (Francis Joseph), 1867-1937 [Editor]; Churchill, Allen L. (Allen Leon), 1873- [Editor]

quoteFirst: At half-past five Captain Tarfag gave the order to commence paying out the obstructions, and at a steady six knots the "Investigator" steamed ahead, her consort, being a slower vessel, having to take the shorter distance--that between the Breakwater and Picklecombe.  Precisely at
quoteLast: the shoreward ends of the nets were secured.
title: The Rival Submarines
author: Westerman, Percy F. (Percy Francis), 1876-1959; Williams, C. Fleming [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: But perhaps she was very busy, doing servant's work in the preparation of her house for visitors.  When he reached the pier gates at
quoteLast: , they were closed, and the obscure vista of the pier as deserted as some northern pier in mid-winter.  Naturally it was closed!  There was a notice prominently displayed that the pier would close that evening at dusk.
title: Clayhanger
author: Bennett, Arnold, 1867-1931

quoteFirst: How could she know he was out on the quest, his eyes on the hill-tops and his head among the stars, slaying monsters and enchanters as he went? How was she to recognize herself as a minor monster? Nevertheless, in unconscious spite of him, she forgot to deliver the message. Gareth, on his arrival at
quoteLast: , impatience having outleapt exactitude, was shown into the dining-room, ruddily illuminated by its first fire of the season. Kathleen had improved the occasion by shampooing her hair, and was now squatting on her heels before the hearth, holding up the long wet strands to the blaze.
title: A marrying man
author: Stern, G. B. (Gladys Bronwyn), 1890-1973

title: The Ascent of the Matterhorn
author: Whymper, Edward, 1840-1911

quoteFirst: After her last report to Lae, at 5:20 P.M. on July 2, something had happened to put her off course. After sunset at
quoteLast: and during the night until sunrise at 6:12 A.M. the next morning, she had somehow become lost.

quoteLast: , just before dark. It had interrupted dinner on our ship; but by and by we went back to the ward-room to finish eating. It is always good business to eat--no knowing when a man will be needing a good meal to be standing by him inside.
title: The U-boat hunters
author: Connolly, James B. (James Brendan), 1868-1957

quoteFirst: Haughton, a great science scholar, of Trinity College, Dublin:--At what time was there high tide in Dublin Bay on the 23rd April, 1014? After a laborious calculation, Dr. Haughton found that the tide was at its height that morning at half-past five o’clock, just as the sun was coming over the horizon, and that the evening tide was in at
quoteLast: : a striking confirmation of the truth of this part of the narrative. It shows, too, that the account was written by or taken down from an eye-witness of the battle. Dr.
title: The Story of Ancient Irish Civilization
author: Joyce, P. W. (Patrick Weston), 1827-1914

quoteFirst: And, as if that weren't enough, his daddy is standing up on a horse and the horse is going round the ring lickety-split. And, as if these circumstances weren't sufficiently trying, that little show-boy is standing on only one foot. The other is stuck up in the air like
quoteLast: , and he has hold of his toe with his hand. I'll bet you can't do that just as you are on the ground, let alone on your daddy's head, and him on a horse that's going like sixty. Now you just try it once. Just try it....
title: Back Home
author: Wood, Eugene, 1860-1923
